text:
Carl Schurz Park: A set of 3 views of the Gracie Mansion, located in the northern end of the Park at what would be the foot of East 88th Street, if the street continued to the East River. This set shows the front of the house, that overlooked the East River. 1913.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

The house was made the official residence of the Mayor of the City of New York on January 8, 1942 by an act of the Board of Estimate.

See "The New York Times," January 9, 1942.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.

text:
(1)
Carl Schurz Park: A view northward from the northern extremity and showing a portion of the Promenade in the foreground. Shown in the background is the Hell Gate Bridge spanning the East River.
1923.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view eastward from the Promenade showing several pleasure boats silhouetted against the Astoria (formerly Dutch Kille) Long Island shore line.
1924.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A view southward from the Promenade, along the East River and showing on the left a portion of Welfare Island. Note the Queensboro Bridge in the distance.
1924.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park (Northward).

text:
Carl Schurz Park: A set of 2 views northeastward, across the East River to Astoria, Long Island. Note the Hellgate (Long Island Connecting Railroad) Bridge on the left. In view No. 1 appears a pier at the foot of East 86th Street with a tug boat that conveys individuals to Welfare (Blackwells) Island, tied thereto.

Spring 1924.
View 2:--June 24, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park (Northeast).

text:
(1) Carl Schurz Park: A view westward on the Promenade, showing the Park on the left and the East River on the right. Beyond East End Ave., East 89th Street begins; upon the north side of which are the buildings of the House of the Good Shepherd. Note the U.S. Volunteer Life Saving Station on the rivers edge.

P. L. Sperr.

August 2, 1927.

(2) The same, from the northwestern corner of the Park.

May 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Promenade; House of The Good Shepherd; United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps.

title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Promenade; House of The Good Shepherd; United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps.

text:
(1)
Carl Schurz Park: A view of the East River frontage of the northern part of the park, with Gracie Mansion there in. Shown in the background are houses on the west side of East End Ave., and the spire atop a building of the House of the Good Shepherd; all at East 89th Street.

August 31, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the south and east (front) sides of the Gracie Mansion as viewed northward from a point in the Park. The East River embankment is on the right.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies, Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(3)
A view similar to No. 2. Note the foot path, benches, and general improvements; a W.P.A. project.
March 29, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

On January 8, 1962, the Board of Estimate designated the Gracie Mansion to the official residence of the Mayor of the City of New York.
See "The New York Times," January 9, 1962, p. 15.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.

text:
Carl Schurz Park: A new pedestrian over pass is in the central portion of the Park; built by the W.P.A. The photographers vantage point is eastward and shows through same the Astoria shoreline across the East River.
August 17, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park.

text:
Carl Schurz Park: A view northward, from the northern extremity of the Park, over the East River, and showing the new "streamlined" Triboro Bridge silhouetted against the curved span of the Hellgate Bridge. This set of 3 views are similar; No. 1, being of a slightly earlier date.

No. 1-------March 29, 1937.
Nos. 2 & 3-August 17, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park (Northward).

text:
Carl Schurz Park: The Gracie Mansion viewed westward and showing the East River frontage.

1939

Gift of George Jiranek
Photostat Division
New York Public Library
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park.
